34.56.text:
Eight years ago, when the UK last held the
G8, hundreds of thousands marched to make

40.44.text:
poverty history. Nelson Mandela stood in Trafalgar
Square and called on humanity to "rise up"

47.83.text:
and free millions "trapped in the prison of
poverty." Unprecedented agreements were reached

53.52.text:
on aid.
And in recent years a combination of economic

56.91.text:
growth and smart aid has helped to deliver
huge advances in cutting poverty. Aid has

63.40.text:
been particularly vital in the fight against
diseases like malaria and polio.

68.73.text:
But eight years later, poverty is still very
much present in many of the countries represented

74.16.text:
here today.
Today I want to talk about why.

78.68.text:
And how I believe we can use this G8 -- and
this meeting here today -- to forge together

84.49.text:
a new agenda that will drive growth for us
all and in doing so finally give us the chance

90.81.text:
to fulfil the ambition of 2005: to eradicate
extreme poverty from our world.

97.01.text:
Let me start with why the problem of poverty
has not gone away. Some will say that promises

103.15.text:
on aid weren't kept. And they would be right.
Britain is one of the few countries in the

109.03.text:
world to have honoured its commitment to spend
0.7 per cent of its Gross National Income

113.95.text:
on aid.
We are proud of that. And we will keep up

122.32.text:
the pressure on our international counterparts
to do the same.

126.35.text:
Some will say that too much aid has been badly
spent. They are right too. All of us need

131.79.text:
to get better at how we use aid. And we are
doing that. That's why Britain is focusing

136.43.text:
our aid on tangible, measureable outcomes
like vaccinating 50 million children against

141.87.text:
preventable diseases and securing schooling
for 20 million.

147.07.text:
But I believe there is an even more fundamental
reason why poverty has not yet been beaten.

152.25.text:
And it's this. We simply can't eradicate poverty
by using aid alone. Yes, aid is vital and

159.20.text:
it has helped to drive extraordinary progress.
But aid inevitably focuses more on the consequences

164.86.text:
of poverty. To eradicate poverty we need to
deal with its causes too.

169.71.text:
That means supporting what I call "the golden
thread" of conditions that enable open economies

174.96.text:
and open societies to thrive the absence of
conflict and corruption, the rule of law,

181.65.text:
free speech and the presence of property rights
and strong institutions. These things aren't

186.19.text:
just valuable in themselves.
They are also vital in providing the foundations

191.25.text:
for the sustained economic growth that can
lift countries out of poverty. It is a simple

196.09.text:
fact that countries beset by corruption and
weak governance are most likely to succumb

201.31.text:
to conflict. And remember this: no country
in conflict has ever met a single one of the

207.97.text:
Millennium Development Goals.
Now a big part of tackling the causes of poverty

212.48.text:
is ensuring that developing countries get
the revenues and the benefits of growth that

216.68.text:
are rightfully theirs. And three vital things
are needed to make that happen.

222.86.text:
Fairer taxes, greater transparency and more
trade.

227.06.text:
The 3 Ts is a snappy title, but, really, why
link these three together? Because they all

235.66.text:
have something in common: in each case developing
countries are badly missing out.

241.93.text:
When taxes are not collected, the poor suffer.
In fact, illicit flows out of African countries

248.58.text:
exceed what they gain in aid. When companies
extracting natural resources like minerals

253.94.text:
and oil are not transparent and don't publish
the payments they make or when governments

259.43.text:
allow these payments to leach away into corruption
people in developing countries miss out on

265.03.text:
the vital revenues they are due.
And when trade is choked by barriers and bureaucracy

270.83.text:
-- developing countries miss out on the chance
to grow. These issues are not just important

277.12.text:
they are ever more urgent too. Developing
countries are finding new sources of natural

281.86.text:
wealth like offshore oil and gas in Ghana
and Tanzania and the forces of globalisation

287.46.text:
are driving ever greater opportunities for
growth and trade.

291.83.text:
Just think what missing out on this growing
income means for a country where thousands

296.46.text:
of children are dying every day because of
malnutrition or where sick parents have to

300.65.text:
choose between whether to buy medicine to
save their own lives, or pay for food for

305.24.text:
their hungry children.
So fairer taxes, greater transparency and

309.70.text:
more trade are three vital and linked weapons
in the war against poverty. And the other

315.97.text:
thing that joins them all together is that
they all need political leadership. Too often

321.40.text:
in the past this has been missing.
Take Equatorial Guinea Africa's third largest

327.81.text:
oil producer where the President has maintained
that oil revenues are a state secret. Action

333.64.text:
by the US Justice Department against the President's
son lists assets allegedly acquired with money

340.30.text:
stolen from the state including a Gulfstream
jet, eight Ferraris, seven Rolls-Royce, a

346.52.text:
$38 million estate in Malibu, and white gloves
previously owned by Michael Jackson. Per capita,

358.60.text:
Equatorial Guinea is richer than Poland -- but
its child death rate is 20 times higher.

365.47.text:
According to Kofi Annan's Africa Progress
Panel, 12 of the 25 countries in the world

373.26.text:
with the highest child mortality rates are
resource-rich African countries. Many of

378.71.text:
these countries should be rich enough not
to need our aid and industrious enough to

382.54.text:
be great trading partners in the years ahead
of us. So I want to break something of a taboo

388.82.text:
today.
For too long the international community has

391.38.text:
shied away from condemning the appalling degree
of corruption and mismanagement of resources

396.77.text:
and the fundamentally bad governance that
is destroying lives in some developing countries.

401.10.text:
And there are always voices saying: why cause
the stir; why be the one to point the finger?

406.24.text:
Well Britain has kept our aid promises so
I don't think we should hold back.

412.81.text:
Corruption is wrong. It starves the poor.
It poisons the system. It saps the faith of

418.17.text:
people in progress. It wrecks the case for
aid. When we see it we should condemn it utterly.

424.56.text:
I know some people put their hands up in the
air and say this can never change. But by

429.60.text:
ending the era of tax secrecy and driving
real openness over what governments and businesses

435.25.text:
do - it can change. And there are political
leaders here are who making that happen.

442.08.text:
President Mahama of Ghana, who has opened
up his country's budget so his people can

446.50.text:
see how their money is spent. President Conde
of Guinea, who has recently led the way on

452.16.text:
publishing mining contracts online. President
Kikwete of Tanzania, who is working to ensure

458.22.text:
that the citizens of his country can enjoy
clear and secure property rights And President

463.10.text:
Sall of Senegal, who has simplified taxes,
unleashed auditors on public finances and

468.53.text:
set up a commission to tackle corruption.
But this needs political leadership from the

476.20.text:
developed world too. We have the tools in
our hands to tackle these problems.

481.64.text:
We can build international tax systems that
make it easier for developing countries to

486.19.text:
collect the taxes they are due. We can ensure
our extractive companies are accountable and

492.72.text:
transparent in their dealings. And we can
do more to promote trade in Africa.

499.07.text:
And the extraordinary thing about this tax,
transparency and trade agenda is that it's

503.74.text:
not just the right thing for us to do morally
it's right for our economies too. Because

509.83.text:
when some businesses don't pay their taxes,
it corrodes public trust. When some companies

515.09.text:
don't play by the rules, that drives more
regulation and makes it harder for other businesses

519.94.text:
to turn a profit. And when Africa doesn't
trade to its potential, we all lose the chance

525.60.text:
to benefit from trading with one of the fastest
growing continents on the planet.

530.38.text:
By 2050 the continent of Africa will have
nearly twice the population of China. And

535.90.text:
a third of the world's youth will live there.
We'd be crazy not to be part of this journey

543.21.text:
with Africa. In short getting tax, transparency
and trade right is good for us and it's vital

549.44.text:
for developing countries too. So let me tell
you what we are going to do.

555.22.text:
First, at the G8 I'm going to push for international
agreements to fight the scourge of tax evasion

561.26.text:
and aggressive tax avoidance. That means automatic
exchange of information between our tax authorities

567.35.text:
-- so those who want to evade taxes have nowhere
to hide. It means getting companies to report

573.60.text:
to tax authorities where they earn their profits
and where they pay their tax. It also means

579.16.text:
transparency about who owns which companies
and who benefits from it -- so called beneficial

588.71.text:
Because some people use complicated and fake
structures to hide their profits and avoid

593.65.text:
taxes and because bribes are often held in
opaquely owned companies with bank accounts

600.04.text:
in secrecy havens.
The UK is today leading the way by committing

604.64.text:
to create a central registry of company ownership. And
this morning I have held meetings with our

610.16.text:
overseas territories and crown dependencies.
Each and every one of our overseas territories

615.59.text:
and crown dependencies has agreed to sign
up to the multi-lateral convention on information

620.79.text:
exchange to exchange information automatically
with the UK and to produce action plans on

628.59.text:
beneficial ownership.
I commend their leadership and I look to other

632.75.text:
international partners to work with their
own territories to reach similar agreements.

637.97.text:
Just as in Britain people get angry when they
work hard, pay their taxes and then see others

642.79.text:
not paying their fair share so we should demand
the same justice and fairness for others in

648.01.text:
developing countries too.
That means we need to put the information

651.72.text:
out there so they can calculate the taxes
they are owed. And we need to help them improve

657.13.text:
their ability to collect taxes. That's what
the UK has done right across the world. In

662.51.text:
Rwanda tax revenues have increased six-fold
in the last decade. In Afghanistan, eight-fold

668.78.text:
since 2004. And in Ethiopia -- nearly a 50
per cent increase between 2007 and 2011.

680.38.text:
So that's why tax is so important. The next
T -- which is linked to it -- is transparency.

686.78.text:
We need real transparency in the payments
companies make and the revenues that governments

691.58.text:
receive. Just think for a moment about the
discovery of North Sea Oil off the coast of

696.95.text:
Britain. It has given this country revenues
of over £150 billion boosting our balance

703.60.text:
of payments by almost £50 billion a year
and supporting nearly half a million jobs.

709.40.text:
Now imagine if we had no transparency over
the way that oil was extracted. Imagine what

715.14.text:
it would have been like if we had most of
our oil revenues taken from us by corrupt

719.62.text:
politicians, officials and companies. Too
often that has been the story for developing

724.61.text:
countries. But with transparency we can change
that.

728.14.text:
In the last few years we have seen huge advances.
Oil, gas and mining companies will now have

734.19.text:
to publish what they pay in every country
and for every project they work on. That's

740.18.text:
already law in America. It's becoming law
in Europe. And will be in Canada too. Governments

746.70.text:
in return are committing to publish what they
receive. Many developing countries made this

751.75.text:
commitment a while ago. Now Britain, France
and America are joining them too. And we hope

757.35.text:
that others will follow suit.
We need to apply the same principles where

760.85.text:
land changes hands too. We need transparency
over who is buying up land and for what purpose

767.17.text:
so that people get a fair deal when they sell
or lease out their land and the property rights

771.96.text:
of people and communities are properly protected.
Today G8 and developing countries have agreed

777.89.text:
to work together to make the most of these
huge advances on both land and extractives.

783.92.text:
And the UK will continue to drive a transparency
revolution in every corner of the world through

789.21.text:
our leadership of the Open Government Partnership.
But to make this work there is something else

793.84.text:
we need to do. And that is to recognise and
get behind heroic individuals who drive this

800.84.text:
agenda on the ground.
People I met this morning like John Githongo

807.29.text:
-- who was willing to blow the whistle on
fraud and corruption in Kenya, at real personal

812.29.text:
cost.
And Aruna Roy, who, almost single-handed,

814.95.text:
brought on the Right to Information revolution
in India helping citizens to secure better

819.47.text:
services and a say in how they are governed.
And that is why we are also welcoming the

824.58.text:
"Transparency Champions Challenge" launched
today by the Open Society Foundations -- to

830.19.text:
provide practical support to people like John
and Aruna around the world.

835.14.text:
So we need fairer taxes and greater transparency
to deal with corruption. But, third, we also

840.93.text:
need trade as the engine of growth. That means
completing the trade deal between the EU and

846.44.text:
Canada and launching one between the EU and
the US.

850.48.text:
But just as important is to make sure that
the growth of trade benefits Africa too. So

855.79.text:
let's back African countries in achieving
their goal of doubling intra-African trade

860.39.text:
by 2022. Let's back Africa in ending the crazy
bureaucracy that means a trucker taking goods

866.77.text:
from Cape Town to Kigali has to carry up to
1000 documents.

872.49.text:
And let's back Africans on infrastructure
-- where they have a point when they say it

876.86.text:
was largely designed in another era and primarily
focused on getting products out of the continent

882.32.text:
rather than promoting trade within it. So
let's get behind President Kaberuka's work

888.07.text:
through the African Development Bank to secure
the private finance that can deliver the infrastructure

893.29.text:
that is so badly needed.
So that's our agenda today and for the UK's

898.06.text:
G8 Summit next week. It is about proper companies,
proper taxes and proper global rules ensuring

922.16.text:
that openness delivers the benefits it should
for rich and poor countries alike. Aid is

927.59.text:
important but these things matter just as
much. Now is the time. This is the agenda

933.29.text: The world should get behind it.
